description: The Admirable Bolete features a distinctive dark reddish-brown to burgundy cap (5-20 cm) with velvety, dry surface. Pores are bright golden-yellow, bruising blue-green. The yellow stem displays burgundy-red tones and has distinctive yellow reticulation. Yellow flesh stains blue when cut. Often grows on decaying hemlock wood - a unique habitat among boletes. Spore print is olive-brown.
habitat: Mycorrhizal with hemlock trees but distinctively fruits on or near decaying hemlock wood, stumps, and logs. Found in old-growth and mature hemlock forests. The wood-associated growth habit is unusual for boletes and diagnostic for this species.
season: Late summer through fall (August-October) with peak fruiting in September. Appears after late summer rains in hemlock habitats.
lookalikes: Boletus species - not on wood, different colors
Leccinum species - scabrous stems, not on wood
The wood-associated growth and burgundy colors are distinctive
safety_notes: EDIBLE: Admirable Bolete is a good edible with firm texture and pleasant flavor. The blue-staining is normal and safe. The unique growth on or near hemlock wood makes identification straightforward. Cook thoroughly before eating. Some people may experience mild digestive upset. Relatively uncommon species.
